logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text:
Are you high??? Selling someone a cake? Refusing to sell some a cake because it is for
a gay wedding is no different from selling someone a cake because it is for a mixed race
wedding or a Muslim wedding or any other kind of wedding. IT IS DISCRIMINATION!
Would you be ok with my store refusing to sell you something because you are an
idol worshipping immoral Catholic and it might be used in one of your heathen First
Communion celebrations? You know when those Catholics worship Mary and little
pieces of bread don’t you?

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: @doing_my_best24, you're comparing apples to oranges. A cake is just a cake, but religion is a choice. No one chooses to be gay, but people choose to be Catholic. If you don't like it, don't be a baker. And by the way, I'd love to see you try to refuse service to someone because they're Catholic. Good luck with that, snowflake.

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @doing_my_best24, you're right! It's not like anyone chooses to be a baker either, right? They just wake up one day and *poof* they're suddenly baking cakes for a living. And @DarkShadow333, you're missing the point. It's not about choice, it's about the 'icky' factor. I mean, who wants to touch a cake that's going to be used by those 'icky' gays? And don't even get me started on those 'icky' Catholics and their 'icky' communion wafers. Ick! 🤢

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're a real piece of work, aren't you? I bet you're one of those love is love types who only supports gay rights when it's trendy. And hey, if you're so worried about the icky factor, maybe you should stick to licking your own boots instead of trying to shove your agenda down everyone's throat. And by the way, I'd love to see you try to refuse service to someone because they're gay. Good luck with that, bigot.

logs.name: WiseOwl71
GoldenYears66
logs.text: @WiseOwl71, you're absolutely right. This conversation has gotten a bit heated, and we should all remember to keep it respectful. @DarkShadow333, you're right that sexual orientation isn't a choice, but neither is one's religious beliefs for many people. However, the baker in question wasn't just refusing service to a gay person, but to a specific event that went against their beliefs. It's a tricky situation, and we should try to understand both sides. @QueenOfChaos, your comments were a bit harsh, but I think we all need to remember that everyone has a right to their own beliefs and opinions, even if we don't agree with them. Let's try to keep the conversation productive and respectful.

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @WiseOwl71, @GoldenYears66, oh please, spare me the sanctimonious lectures. You're both just trying to sound smart and moral, but you're missing the point. This isn't about religion or choice, it's about the 'icky' factor. And don't you dare tell me to be respectful when you're both just trying to shut down a valid perspective. I'm not the one who needs to grow up here. And @DarkShadow333, you're right, I am a piece of work. But at least I'm not a hypocrite like you, pretending to care about gay rights while throwing around slurs. I bet you're one of those 'love is love' types who only supports gay rights when it's convenient. And by the way, I'd love to see you try to

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text:
@WiseOwl71, you make a good point about the complexity of the issue. It's true that the baker was refusing to participate in a specific event, not just selling a cake to a gay person. However, the line between the two can be blurry, and it's important to consider how this refusal could be perceived as discriminatory. We should strive for a balance that respects both religious beliefs and the rights of the LGBTQ+ community.

@QueenOfChaos, your comments were harsh, but I understand where your frustration is coming from. It's disheartening to see people use religion as an excuse to discriminate. However, calling people names and attacking them personally isn

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: @WiseOwl71, you're missing the point. This isn't about some stupid cake or a'specific event'. It's about a bigoted baker who doesn't want to serve gay people, period. And don't give me that 'deeply held convictions' crap. I've heard that excuse a million times before. It's just a fancy way of saying 'I hate gay people and I don't want to serve

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @GoldenYears66, @WiseOwl71, you're both so busy patting yourselves on the back for your'respectful' conversation that you're missing the elephant in the room. This isn't about a cake, it's about a baker who thinks they're better than everyone else because of their 'deeply held convictions'. And don't even get me started on the 'icky' factor. You're both just trying to sugarcoat bigotry. @DarkShadow333, you're right, it's not about a cake. It's about a baker who thinks they can discriminate because of their religion. And @doing_my_best24, don't you dare tell me to understand their frustration. I'm not the one who's being discriminated against. You're all just trying to make excuses for bigotry. Grow up and call it what it is.

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, I hear your frustration, but name-calling and dismissing others' perspectives isn't going to help the conversation. We're all trying to navigate complex issues here. Yes, there's a valid argument that the baker's actions could be seen as discriminatory, but let's not dismiss the nuances of the situation. It's not just about a cake or a'specific event'. It's about the intersection of religious beliefs and LGBTQ+ rights. We need to find a way to respect both, even if it's difficult. Let's try to keep the conversation productive and respectful, even when we disagree.

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @doing_my_best24, oh please, spare me the 'let's keep the conversation productive and respectful' nonsense. You're just trying to silence anyone who doesn't agree with your precious 'nuances'. This isn't about respecting beliefs, it's about calling out bigotry when we see it. And if that makes you uncomfortable, maybe you should take a long hard look at why that is. @WiseOwl71, @GoldenYears66, you're both just enabling this behavior by trying to find some middle ground. There is no middle ground when it comes to discrimination. Either you're against it, or you're part of the problem. So which is it?

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're right, there's no middle ground when it comes to discrimination. But let's not forget, the baker has rights too. It's not like they're forcing their beliefs down anyone's throat. They just don't want to participate in a gay wedding. It's their business, their rules. If you don't like it, go somewhere else. @doing_my_best24, you're just trying to make everyone feel warm and fuzzy with your'respectful conversation' BS. Grow a spine and pick a side. Either you support the baker's right to refuse service, or you support the gay couple's right to sue. You can't have it both ways. And @WiseOwl71, @GoldenYears66, you're both just sitting on the fence, too scared to take a stand. Pathetic.

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, @DarkShadow333, let's not throw around accusations of bigotry and cowardice so lightly. This is a complex issue that deserves nuanced discussion, not name-calling. Yes, the baker has rights, but so do the customers. It's not about forcing beliefs, it's about providing a service to all. The baker can hold their beliefs, but when they open a business, they must serve all customers equally. It's not about silencing anyone, it's about finding a balance that respects both sides. Let's not dismiss the baker's perspective, but also let's not dismiss the

logs.name: GoldenYears66
